Key: Ohh...
Heeeey, Tohka. Tohka-saaaaan?
Hrngh...
No use. She can't hear me at all.

(She's been stuck at a glass window for the
past thirty minutes, staring at cute animals
in a pet shop.)

It is so fluffy.. Look how many fluffy things
there are!
Oh, it's moving...
It ran. Oh, it fell!
...It rolled up into a ball.

Aw, cute. They are so precious, don't you
think, Shido?
Yeah. Watching them is therapeutic.
Yes, for me as well!

(Tohka was staring at a litter of puppies
playing with one another inside of an
enclosure, rolling around.)

(Tohka began mimicking the puppies,
beginning to roll around on the floor.)
Ohh... Ohhh...

(When the dogs go right, she goes right.
If they go left, she goes left. She is in total
sync with the pups.)

(It was pretty entertaining to watch from
behind her.)
Shido, look. They are so cute.
Let's see.

(I peeked inside the window, and a puppy
jumped.)
Wow. They look like plushies.
I know, I know! Ahh, so cute...

(Tohka's eyes were entranced. She was
utterly attached to the pups.)

(I didn't know she had a soft spot for puppies.
We just happened to pass the pet shop.)

(The only other time her eyes sparkle like
this is when she's gazing at food samples.)

(I guess to her, food and pets occupy the
same plane of worship.)
Hm? They ceased moving, Shido.
Hm?

(I looked once more at the puppies. One was
face down, and the other was belly up, lying
beside its sibling.)
Sounds like nap time to me.

I think they're sleeping? I mean, they say
puppies spend most of their day napping.
I bet they're tired from playing so much.
I see. Aww. That is too bad.

(Tohka stepped back away from the pet shop
quietly. Keeping one eye fixed on the puppies,
she took gentle steps to not wake them.)
Satisfied?
I am good for today, but I wish to return.
Sure. We'll come back soon.
Okay.
So long, friends.

(She bid the showcase farewell, and waved
her hand. The puppies likely didn't hear her,
but they responded with a yawn.)
Hehe.

(She seemed entertained. Maybe we could
take a zoo trip someday.)
Ah. It's a nice day.

(We sat on a bench and stretched out our
hands and feet.)
Yes. The weather is perfect. So temperate.

A laidback day like this is just what I need
now and then.
(Tohka responded with a kind smile.)

(Today, we didn't have anything specific
planned for our date. We walked around the
shopping district and entered random shops.)

(The pet shop was one of them. We chose
it on a whim, but it left an impression.)

(The park was a perfect follow-up. We
basked in the sunshine together.)

(Can't take ordinary days like this for
granted. I'm getting emotional thinking
about it.)
Shido, look. There is a dog over there!
Hm? Oh, you're right.

(Just below us on the path, someone was
walking their dog.)

(It was relatively big, wagging its tail as it
trotted beside its owner.)
Lucky. It looks friendly and fluffy.
Do you want a pet, Tohka? Like a dog?
Yes. Having a pet looks delightful.

It seems like you enjoyed yourself at the
pet store.
I only wish to snuggle with a large dog.

I want to take naps with it, perhaps throw
a branch and play fetch.

What about pets that are easier to take care
of? Like a hamster or parakeet? I hear some
people keep turtles or iguanas as pets, too.
Oh, really? Were they at the pet shop as well?

Probably. They're small, so I bet they kept
them in the back.

(The larger pets are placed towards the front
of the store. Tohka was so enthralled that I'm
sure she didn't notice.)
So pets come in a variety, do they?

Hamsters are small and cute, and parakeets
are birds. Enticing options, indeed. In an
emergency, they can be last-resort meals.

You better not eat your pets. Promise me
you won't.

(I like to think she's kidding, but knowing
Tohka, there might be a kernel of truth in
there. I need to keep an eye out...)

I was thinking that neither turtles nor iguanas
have hair. They don't qualify as fluffy, do they?

Ah. You've got a point. If you want a fluffy
pet, then those options wouldn't work.

(If she wants to cuddle fur, then it has to
be a dog or a cat. Guess she's not too into
reptiles.)

(I wonder what kind of dog owner she would
be. Tohka's as bubbly and sociable as a dog.)

(If they're together, they might mesh well and
go on walks every day. But I could also see them
clashing, getting into rowdy arguments.)

(Regardless, that sounds fun. Maybe it's
worth looking into a dog.)
Hm? It's coming this way.
...Really?!
(The dog pranced towards us.)

(Its owner seemed to be chatting with an
acquaintance, and the dog grew bored.)
Oh, this one is friendly. Come hither.

(Tohka beckoned to it, and the dog neared.
It seemed accustomed to people.)

(Tohka let out a small, welcoming squeal
as she pet the dog. It merely sat there,
calmly enjoying the attention.)
It's so fluffy. I like how it feels, Shido.

That's nice. It doesn't even bark. What a
good dog.

(I reached out to the dog as Tohka had,
and it licked my hand.)

(As I pet its head, it wagged its tail. It really
was a cute dog.)

All right. This is as good of an opportunity
as ever to train it.

Hey, are you serious? Train it? How would
you do that, Tohka?
Leave it to me. Watch and learn, Shido.

(She seemed so confident, but I doubt Tohka
had ever trained a dog before. She must have
gotten her info from TV. I hope she's okay...)
Here I go. Shake!

(*shake*! The dog did as it was commanded,
and offered its paw.)
Whoaaaaaa, amazing!
Sit!

(*sit*! It placed its bottom on the grass,
almost showing off how prompt it was.)
Tohka, that's amazing!
Do three aerial galaxy twists!
That's too much!
NO WAAAAAAY!

(It was a perfect somersault. If there were
judges, they'd award the dog a perfect 10.
Was this dog raised in a circus?)
Ah! What a smart dog!

(Tohka was elated, and the dog responded
well to its praise, pressing its collar against
Tohka when―)
(It dove its nose into Tohka's skirt.)
Ah... H-Hey!
Wha, wha, wha?!
W-Wait, my skirt is going to flip!

(Tohka tried to press her skirt down, but
dog was unrelenting.)

(Her thighs were becoming exposed.
Oh, no! Tohka's in trouble!)
Help her.
Sit and watch.

Sh-Shido! Why are you just sitting there?!
Help me!

(She didn't have to ask twice. I put my body
in between Tohka and the dog.)
There, there.

(I pet its head and its neck. The dog groaned
from comfort.)

(Tohka used this opportunity to hide behind
me.)
*whimper*...

Don't glare at it. It just wanted to play with
you.
Shido, did you see it...?
Uh...

(I couldn't deny it. Tohka's skin was pale
white.)
Aww...
Oh, um... Er...
Whoa!

(All of a sudden, the dog barked and Tohka
jumped on me! All right... Great timing!)
Sh-Shido! Is it coming for me again?
(Huh? Did that... traumatize her?)
Go, get back. Your owner's waiting for you.

(The dog cocked its head, so I shooed it
towards its owner. After a few minutes,
the dog understood what I was doing.)

(It ran back to its owner, periodically looking
back at us in the distance.)
Haha. That dog had a lot of personality.

(I was sad to say good-bye, so I waved at it.
The owner acknowledged me with a bow.)
Yes. It did, but...
But?

The dog appeared cute, but I had a feeling that
it was eyeing my skirt from the start.
No, I don't think that's the case.
Oh, then if you say so.
(Looks like Tohka was shaken up by it.)
Sh-Shido! Don't just watch! Do something!
Yeah, but...

(The dog buried its head up Tohka's skirt.
If I were to get in between them, I'd have
to hop in front of Tohka, but...)

(That would also mean I'd have to look
up her skirt.)
Hey, where are you licking?! HYAH!
Aah... N-No. Not there...
(What the―?! This is getting weird!)
C-Cut it...
AAAAAH!
Aah... MMM...
T-Tohka!!
Sh-Shido... Do something.
I-I'll save you now!
Hey. Stop it. It tickles... AAAAU!
T-Tohka!!

(She became weak from being tickled, and
I rushed to catch her. It was close.)
Y-You should've helped me sooner...
(She looked at me drearily, and I gulped.)
S-Sorry... Are you okay?
Y-Yeah...
I guess it was a little too playful.

(I pat the dog's head. It seemed satisfied,
and wagged its tail. Little guy didn't have
a care in the world.)

Well, I think it just wanted to play. Go on.
Go back to your master.

(I called at the dog, and it cooed before
walking over to its owner.)
I cannot tell if I am sad or relieved. Hm...
(Hahaha. That must've been rough for Tohka.)

(Before we knew it, the sun was beginning to
set. I could hear a crow cawing from afar.)
*sigh*... What a day.

I realized that playing with a dog is very
involving...

(Her realization was expressed with a pouty
face, only a little deflated from earlier.)
But it was fun, wasn't it?
Yeah! Really fun!

Great. Do you want to play with dogs again
in the future?

That is debatable. It depends on whether or
not the dog is obedient.
Sure, but you got it to do some cool tricks.

(To command a dog you've met for the first
time to do a triple flip is out of this world.)
But I couldn't make it listen to me...

Who cares? I mean, no one can do everything,
right? You did your best, right Tohka? That's
all that matters.
Shido... Thank you.

Nothing to thank me for. Tohka, do you want
to get dinner? Anything you want.
Oh! Then what should I do...?

You better hurry, or I'll pick a vegetarian
meal.

What?! Wait a minute, Shido! I'll come up
with something right now! Hm...

Haha. I'm kidding, but I'll wait until we're
close to the market.
Okay, got it!

(Delicious food always made Tohka smile.
I remembered her playing with the dog, and
I couldn't help giving a wry smile.)
